children.heading: Document Purpose
children.text: This Software Requirements Specification (SRS) establishes the complete requirements for the Smart Waste Management & Recycling System (SWMRS) – the product developed by The Junkers for the City of Kamloops. The target audience includes software developers, project managers, client representatives, city administrators, collection workers, residents, maintainers, QA/testers, and documentation writers. Its purpose is to define detailed, traceable requirements based on the vision from Assignment 1 and extended through requirements elicitation in Assignment 2.

children.heading: Document Conventions
children.text:
• Each requirement, objective, and risk in this document is assigned a unique identifier for traceability (e.g., OBJ-01, REQ-10, RSK-05) as per best SRS practices.
  • Use cases are prefixed UC-XX (e.g., UC-01).
  • High, Medium, or Low priority is noted in italics after each feature descriptor.
  • All referenced documents follow IEEE citation guidelines.
  • Terminology and abbreviations are defined in Section 9 (Glossary).
  • Tables or numbered paragraphs are used instead of unstructured lists for all formally referenced items.

children.heading: Project Scope
children.text:
SWMRS is an integrated municipal software solution that will use IoT-enabled waste bin sensors, intelligent routing, mobile and web interfaces, and real-time analytics to enhance the efficiency of waste/recycling collection and community engagement in Kamloops. Major objectives include:

OBJ-01. Reduce operational expenditures by 20% in the first year through route optimization.

OBJ-02. Increase recycling rates by at least 30% by year-end via resident point-based gamification.

OBJ-03. Achieve a 15% reduction in missed collections through automated fill-level monitoring and alerts.

OBJ-04. Lower the city sanitation fleet’s carbon emissions by 10% by minimizing unnecessary travel.

The scope and business context are established in the Vision & Scope Document (VSD), with this SRS focusing on requirements for the initial release of the SWMRS.

children.heading: References
children.text:
• Vision & Scope Doc - The Junkers, v1.0, Oct 2025
  • City of Kamloops Waste Management Policy, 2025
  • Assignment #2 - SENG 3130, User Requirement Details
  • IEEE SRS Standard, 2020
  • (Other technical references and source materials as needed)

data.heading: Overall Description
data.text: This section provides a high-level overview of the SWMRS, its users, the primary operating environment, major constraints, and foundational project assumptions.

children.heading: Product Perspective
children.text: SWMRS is a newly designed, city-wide, data-driven SaaS platform intended to replace Kamloops’ legacy manual and partially-digital waste management processes. It is architected to interact with decentralized IoT smart bins, municipal and contractor staff, resident users (via mobile/web), and a rewards vendor network. The SWMRS is the hub for data collection, monitoring, routing optimization, reward calculation, and cross-stakeholder communication.

children.heading: User Classes and Characteristics
children.text:
User Class​​​​​TypeDescriptionFavourability 
Collection WorkerDirect
Uses mobile app to view routes, report issues, confirm work
Favoured 
City AdministratorDirect
Oversees system/operations, generates compliance reports
Favoured
ResidentDirect
Receives notifications, reports issues, tracks rewards
Favoured
SupervisorDirect
Manages exceptions, approves/denies reports
Favoured
Maintenance TechnicianIndirectResponds to sensor/truck faults and audit triggers
Favoured
Local Business PartnerIndirectProvides and manages resident rewards
Favoured
Data AttackerIndirectThreatens system security (handled via security systems)
Unfavored
Unauthorized UserDirect
Attempts system breach or unauthorized actions
Unfavored

children.heading: Use Cases and Models
children.text:
The primary use cases for SWMRS are as follows:

UC-01. Optimize Collection Route

UC-02. Report Missed Pickup/Issue

UC-03. Resident Track Recycling Rewards

UC-04. Worker Pickup Confirmation

UC-05. City Admin Monitor Fleet/Sensor Dashboard

UC-06. Supervisor Manage Exceptions (approve/reject)

UC-07. Sensor Health and Alerts

UC-08. Manage Rewards Catalog

Model diagrams (use case, context, and activity) are provided in the assignment appendix.

children.heading: Operating Environment
children.text:
• Mobile platforms: Android 12.0+ and iOS 16.0+ for both resident and worker apps.
  • Backend: Municipally managed secure servers (Windows Server 2019+ or Linux 22.04+), or cloud-based (Azure/GCP).
  • IoT modules: LoRaWAN/Zigbee/3G/4G integration for bin telemetry.
  • APIs: RESTful endpoints for traffic/weather integration and third-party rewards partners.
  • City office web portals deployed on secure municipal intranet.

children.heading: Design and Implementation Constraints
children.text:
• Comply with City of Kamloops and BC privacy/security policy.
  • Integration limited to officially certified IoT sensor vendors.
  • Mobile applications must function in offline mode with eventual data sync for workers.
  • All interfaces WCAG 2.1 Level AA accessible.
  • Open, documented APIs only; no legacy, proprietary, or closed-source dependencies in the first release.

children.heading: Assumptions and Dependencies
children.text:
• Sufficient mobile device and connectivity coverage for field staff and residents.
  • Regular calibration/maintenance of deployed sensor units.
  • Stable partnerships with rewards vendors.
  • Staff will be trained in mobile/web platforms.
  • Timely third-party API responses for route optimization.
  • Future expansion to other municipalities or language markets will be a separate scope.

children.heading: Description
children.text:
Priority: High

Dynamically generates and updates optimized collection routes for workers, leveraging real-time sensor data, traffic conditions, and administrator settings. Minimizes operational costs and reduces missed or late pickups.

children.heading: Stimulus/Response Sequences
children.text:
• Worker launches mobile app at start of shift → System downloads current optimal route (SRQ-01).
  • Bin sensor reports fill level ≥ threshold during route → System recalculates and adjusts route, notifies worker in-app (SRQ-02).
  • Worker enters area with poor connectivity → App switches to offline cached route, syncs updates when reconnected (SRQ-03).

children.heading: Functional Requirements
children.text:
Req IDRequirement Description
REQ-001System shall use real-time bin sensor data to calculate optimal pickup order.
REQ-002
System must integrate live traffic data from external APIs when proposing a route.
REQ-003
Workers using the mobile app must be able to download and view their daily route with map support.
REQ-004
Application must support offline access for routes, with data syncing after connectivity returns.
REQ-005
Route changes must be logged and auditable by supervisors.
REQ-006
Worker must receive in-app notifications for urgent reroutes or bin status changes en route.
REQ-007
System must record all completed pickups along with timestamps and GPS location.
REQ-008
Administrator must be able to define/adjust routing rules and thresholds.

children.heading: Description
children.text:
Priority: High

Enables IoT-enabled bins to continuously monitor and report fill levels, contamination, and obstructions to the SWMRS server for status tracking, operational decisions, and auditability.

children.heading: Stimulus/Response Sequences
children.text:
• Bin sensor transmits fill level, contamination, and status data every 10 minutes → System updates bin status in dashboard (SRQ-04).
  • Unusual sensor reading (e.g., >100% full, no data for 24h) → System alerts maintenance technician and disables bin from routing until resolved (SRQ-05).

attributesChanged.text:
Priority: High

Enables IoT-enabled bins to continuously monitor and report fill levels, contamination, and obstructions to the SWMRS server for status tracking, operational decisions, and auditability.

children.heading: Functional Requirements
children.text:
Req IDRequirement Description
REQ-009Each bin must report fill level, contamination, and access status to the server at least every 10 min.
REQ-010
Sensor data shall be transferred using encrypted protocols.
REQ-011
System must flag any bin not reporting data for over 24 hours.
REQ-012
Sensor anomalies (impossible data, eg. >150%) are to be auto-flagged and excluded from routing.
REQ-013
Technician must receive maintenance alert for flagged bins.
REQ-014
All bin status data must be retained and auditable for at least 2 years.

children.heading: Description
children.text:
Priority: High

Allows residents to track their collection schedules, receive proactive notifications, report missed pickups/issues, and view participation/rewards via a secure, intuitive mobile app.

children.heading: Stimulus/Response Sequences
children.text:
• Resident opens app to check schedule → System displays bin status, next scheduled pickup, and remaining days (SRQ-06).
  • Resident receives notification (“Pickup tomorrow”, “Pickup complete”, or “Skipped: contamination”) (SRQ-07).
  • Resident identifies a missed pickup and submits an issue report with description and photo; system logs event and notifies supervisor (SRQ-08).

children.heading: Functional Requirements
children.text:
Req IDRequirement Description
REQ-015Mobile app must display personalized collection day and history using geolocation and bin ID.
REQ-016
App must deliver push notifications for upcoming and completed pickups, and skip explanations.
REQ-017
Residents must be able to submit skipped pickup/issue reports with geotagged photo and text.
REQ-018
Complaint/issue reports must generate case numbers trackable by both resident and supervisor.
REQ-019
Residents shall view their recycling score, total points, and rewards catalog in-app.
REQ-020
App must comply with accessibility standards (WCAG 2.1 AA).

children.heading: Description
children.text:
Priority: Medium

Implements a transparent points-based program tracking resident recycling via unique bin IDs and enables redemption of points in a reward catalog sponsored by local businesses.

children.heading: Stimulus/Response
children.text:
• Bin is collected and weighed, or recycling event logged → System credits resident’s reward points based on grade and volume (SRQ-09).
  • Resident redeems points for a local business voucher → System issues voucher code or QR, updates points tally (SRQ-10).

children.heading: Functional Requirements
children.text:
Req IDRequirement Description
REQ-021System must track recycling score/history per resident-linked bin.
REQ-022
Points must be calculated and added in real time after successful recycling pickups.
REQ-023
Residents must be able to view, browse, and redeem from the up-to-date rewards catalog in the app.
REQ-024
Redemption events must trigger notification to both resident and business sponsor.
REQ-025
All redemption and earning data must be retained for at least two years.

children.heading: Description
children.text:
Priority: High

Provides city administrators and supervisors a comprehensive dashboard that displays real-time truck status, route progress, missed pickups, fuel usage, compliance analytics, and system warnings for proactive operational management.

children.heading: Stimulus/Response Sequences
children.text:
• Administrator logs in to dashboard → System displays fleet map, truck/bins status, active alerts (SRQ-11).
  • Analytics module triggers urgent alert for 90% full bins or missed pickups → System enables quick re-routing or dispatch action (SRQ-12).

children.heading: Functional Requirements
children.text:
Req IDRequirement Description
REQ-026Dashboard must provide real-time status of all trucks, assets, and monitored bins.
REQ-027
Must display live route changes and allow filtering by status, region, or event type.
REQ-028
Enable administrators to adjust optimization parameters (fill threshold, zone priorities, etc.).
REQ-029
System must generate downloadable reports on performance and compliance with selectable filters.
REQ-030
Issue urgent alerts for high fill bins and sensor failures, integrating override options.

REQ-027

REQ-029

REQ-030
All redemption and earning data must be retained for at least two years.

data.heading: Data Requirements
data.text: This section describes all data objects and models processed or generated by SWMRS, as well as requirements related to acquisition, protection, retention, and deletion. It is written to ensure that data is both usable and auditable, meeting city standards and privacy policies.

children.heading: Logical Data Model
children.text:
The SWMRS maintains relational data for waste bins, users, events, vehicles, reports, and rewards. The following high-level entities are modeled:

  • Bin (BinID, Location, FillLevel, ContaminationStatus, LastServiceDate, SensorHealth)
  • Resident (ResidentID, Address, LinkedBinID, RecyclingScore, RewardPoints, ContactInfo)
  • Worker (WorkerID, Name, AssignedRouteID, VehicleID)
  • Truck (TruckID, Registration, GPSLocation, FuelUsage, MaintenanceStatus)
  • CollectionEvent (EventID, TruckID, BinID, Timestamp, PickupConfirmed)
  • Complaint (ComplaintID, ResidentID, BinID, Type, PhotoURL, Status, ResolutionDate)
  • Reward (RewardID, PartnerID, Description, PointsRequired, DateRedeemed)
  • Supervisor (SupervisorID, Name, Role, ApprovalActions)
  • Partner (PartnerID, Name, VoucherFormat, RedemptionURL)

The relationships between these entities are shown in an ER diagram included in the appendices and referenced for database implementation.

children.heading: Data Dictionary
children.text:
Each important data structure is defined with allowed types and formats for validation and consistency:

Field NameTypeLengthFormatAllowed Values \ RangeDescription
BinIDString12AlphanumericUnique, A-Z 0-9Smart Waste Bin ID
FillLevelFloatn/aPercentage0.0-150.0Level of Waste
ContaminationStatusEnumn/aStatus CodeClean, Minor, MajorRecycling contamination
ResidentIDString16Alphanumeric
Unique
Resident account ID
RecyclingScoreIntegern/a
n/a0-9999Cumulative points
CompliantTypeEnumn/a
PredefinedMissedPickup, Obstruction, Contamination
Type of issue
PhotoURLString128URLValid image link
Complaint evidence
EventIDString16Alphanumeric
Unique
Collection event
RewardIDString10Alphanumeric
Unique
Reward catalog item
PointsRequiredIntegern/a
n/aPositiveNeeded for redemption
GPSLocationString32Decimal, commaLat/LongTruck/route geotag

Additional details for rarely used fields are maintained in the system’s central data dictionary and regularly updated as requirements evolve.

<If your application will generate any reports, identify them here and describe their characteristics. If a report must conform to a specific predefined layout you can specify that here as a constraint, perhaps with an example. Otherwise, focus on the logical descriptions of the report content, sort sequence, totaling levels, and so forth, deferring the detailed report layout to the design stage.>

children.heading: Data Acquisition, Integrity, Retention, and Disposal

children.text: <If relevant, describe how data is acquired and maintained. State any requirements regarding the need to protect the integrity of the system's data. Identify any specific techniques that are necessary, such as backups, checkpointing, mirroring, or data accuracy verification. State policies the system must enforce for either retaining or disposing of data, including temporary data, metadata, residual data (such as deleted records), cached data, local copies, archives, and interim backups.>
<This section provides information to ensure that the system will communicate properly with users and with external hardware or software elements.>

<Describe the logical characteristics of each interface between the software product and the users. This may include sample screen images, any GUI standards or product family style guides that are to be followed, screen layout constraints, standard buttons and functions (e.g., help) that will appear on every screen, keyboard shortcuts, error message display standards, and so on. Define the software components for which a user interface is needed. Details of the user interface design should be documented in a separate user interface specification.>

<Describe the connections between this product and other software components (identified by name and version), including other applications, databases, operating systems, tools, libraries, websites, and integrated commercial components. State the purpose, formats, and contents of the messages, data, and control values exchanged between the software components. Specify the mappings of input and output data between the systems and any translations that need to be made for the data to get from one system to the other. Describe the services needed by or from external software components and the nature of the intercomponent communications. Identify data that will be exchanged between or shared across software components. Specify nonfunctional requirements affecting the interface, such as service levels for responses times and frequencies, or security controls and restrictions.>

<Describe the characteristics of each interface between the software and hardware (if any) components of the system. This description might include the supported device types, the data and control interactions between the software and the hardware, and the communication protocols to be used. List the inputs and outputs, their formats, their valid values or ranges, and any timing issues developers need to be aware of. If this information is extensive, consider creating a separate interface specification document.>

<State the requirements for any communication functions the product will use, including e-mail, Web browser, network protocols, and electronic forms. Define any pertinent message formatting. Specify communication security or encryption issues, data transfer rates, handshaking, and synchronization mechanisms. State any constraints around these interfaces, such as whether e-mail attachments are acceptable or not.>

<Specify any requirements regarding characteristics that will make the software appear to be “user-friendly.” Usability encompasses ease of use, ease of learning; memorability; error avoidance, handling, and recovery; efficiency of interactions; accessibility; and ergonomics. Sometimes these can conflict with each other, as with ease of use over ease of learning. Indicate any user interface design standards or guidelines to which the application must conform.>

<State specific performance requirements for various system operations. If different functional requirements or features have different performance requirements, it's appropriate to specify those performance goals right with the corresponding functional requirements, rather than collecting them in this section.>

<Specify any requirements regarding security or privacy issues that restrict access to or use of the product. These could refer to physical, data, or software security. Security requirements often originate in business rules, so identify any security or privacy policies or regulations to which the product must conform. If these are documented in a business rules repository, just refer to them.>

<Specify requirements that are concerned with possible loss, damage, or harm that could result from use of the product. Define any safeguards or actions that must be taken, as well as potentially dangerous actions that must be prevented. Identify any safety certifications, policies, or regulations to which the product must conform.>

<Create a separate section in the SRS for each additional product quality attribute to describe characteristics that will be important to either customers or developers. Possibilities include availability, efficiency, installability, integrity, interoperability, modifiability, portability, reliability, reusability, robustness, scalability, and verifiability. Write these to be specific, quantitative, and verifiable. Clarify the relative priorities for various attributes, such as security over performance.>

<Internationalization and localization requirements ensure that the product will be suitable for use in nations, cultures, and geographic locations other than those in which it was created. Such requirements might address differences in: currency; formatting of dates, numbers, addresses, and telephone numbers; language, including national spelling conventions within the same language (such as American versus British English), symbols used, and character sets; given name and family name order; time zones; international regulations and laws; cultural and political issues; paper sizes used; weights and measures; electrical voltages and plug shapes; and many others.>

<Examples are: legal, regulatory or financial compliance, and standards requirements; requirements for product installation, configuration, startup, and shutdown; and logging, monitoring and audit trail requirements. Instead of just combining these all under "Other," add any new sections to the template that are pertinent to your project. Omit this section if all your requirements are accommodated in other sections. >

<Define any specialized terms that a reader needs to know to understand the SRS, including acronyms and abbreviations. Spell out each acronym and provide its definition. Consider building a reusable enterprise-level glossary that spans multiple projects and incorporating by reference any terms that pertain to this project.>

<This optional section includes or points to pertinent analysis models such as data flow diagrams, feature trees, state-transition diagrams, or entity-relationship diagrams. You might prefer to insert certain models into the relevant sections of the specification instead of collecting them at the end.>
